description.narrative:
BHW, through this proposed project, will attain the following change (outcome/purpose):- A more responsive healthcare system that delivers better quality, more transparent and equitable healthcare for all being informed by peoples participation and voice. The above outcome will contribute to health of all citizens, especially marginalized, hard-to-reach, poor, populations particularly women and young girls. The following outputs will lead to the aforementioned outcome: i. Civil society platforms/individual voices enabled to hold government (and other actors) accountable to major health sector commitments ii. Changes in policy/practices as a result of evidence based advocacy carried out to improve the situation related to quality of care, transparency and equity iii. Understanding of duty bearers on quality of care, transparency and equity enhanced.
In order to achieve the above three outputs, three main sets of activities, will be carried out: a) Planned advocacy to enable civil society platforms/individual voices to hold the government accountable to major health sector commitments b) Evidence based, topical advocacy on situation of quality of care, transparency and equity in the health sector c) A multi-pronged approach to improve awareness and understanding of duty-bearers on quality of care, accountability and equity.
The following assumptions will apply to the Theory of Change: From Activities to Outputs - CSOs will participate in BHW activities and share necessary information - Government officials at all levels will be supportive to bring civil society inputs to improving performance of the sector - Government officials will be open to constructive criticism From Outputs to Outcome - Government will remain committed to universal health coverage and SDGs - Government will continue to prioritise Quality of Care, equity and accountability issues - Government will remain committed to peoples participation and engagement - Government will continue taking evidence based policy decisions

Bangladesh Health Watch (BHW), is an independent platform of citizens in various areas of the health sector, working within the structures and framework of James P Grant School of Public Health under BRAC University. Founded in 2006, BHW has so far published six Health Watch Reports on health issues (equity, health workforce, health sector governance, UHC, urban health and NCDs). Through this project, BHW intend to play a wider and stronger role in raising issues and concerns facing the national health sector, suggest solutions and support and lobby the government in achieving its programmatic goals. BHW, through this project aim to attain the following change: “A more responsive healthcare system that delivers more equitable, accessible and better-quality healthcare being informed by people’s voices”.

Bangladesh Health Watch (BHW), är en oberoende plattform inom hälsosektorn och arbetar inom ramarna för James P Grant School of Public Health under BRAC University. BHW grundades 2006 och har hittills publicerat sex Health Watch-rapporter om hälsofrågor (jämlik tillgång till hälsovård, hälso- och sjukvårdspersonal, förvaltning av hälsosektorn, allmän tillgång till hälsovård, urban hälsa och icke-smittsamma sjukdomar). Genom denna insats avser BHW ta en bredare och starkare roll för att ta upp frågor och problem som den nationella hälsosektorn står inför, föreslå lösningar och stödja regeringen i att uppnå sina programmål. BHW, vill genom denna insats uppnå följande förändring: ”Ett mer lyhört hälso- och sjukvårdssystem som ger mer rättvis, tillgänglig och bättre kvalitet på vård som informerats av människors uttryckta behov.

description.narrative: Established an office at the new premises of James P Grant School of Public Health (JPGSPH), BRAC University. - BHW secretariat is fully established now. Major positions were recruited in the first year according as per the project organogram. - A Programme Support Officer was employed on April 01, 2021. Recruitment of a second Programme Officer (Networking and Liaison) has also been done and he joined on July 1, 2021. The second officer plays an important role in communicating with media to disseminate BHW results. - Due to the pandemic the establishment of the regional chapters were delayed during the year 2020. This also lead to a slower burn rate than expected whereby only 2MSEK were disbursed December 2020. - With the pandemic improving and the lock down eliminated the regional chapters are being established during the year 2021 which is an important part of the overall project to be the voice of the people. - Bangladesh Health Watch has launched a new pop-up button on the BHW official website: https://bangladeshhealthwatch.org/. In Bangladesh, there is established platform where citizens can talk about the experience/issues, problems or challenges they face within the health sector. The citizens concerns are thereafter referred to responsible people within the health ministry for answers. - BHW has during the pandemic established themselves as a reliable watch dog. During the year 2021, reports and opinions from Bangladesh Health Watch have been published in 52 newspaper articles (Bangla and English), broadcast in 7 TV news broadcasts and BHW has held several webinars that have reached both ordinary citizens and responsible government officials. - An example of a webinar is a review of the government's health budget together with decision-making officials where areas of underinvestment in healthcare were highlighted and where faster access to UHC was demanded. This session was attended by higher level government officials. -A thematic vaccination group was established which advised Bangladesh on the national vaccine implementation where, among other things, a longer time between the first and second dose of Astra Zeneca dose was recommended to improve the immune response but also facilitate the lack of vaccine deliveries from India. - BHW also made sure to disseminate important study results from ICDDR, B regarding covid infections and risk of covid infection in Dhaka slum areas to the public and healthcare managers through a well-attended webinar. - BHW will organize journalist workshops to strengthen their ability to write and report on health care in Bangladesh. In the planning stage of the workshop a synergy was found with MRDI which is an ongoing collaboration with the Gender and Human Rights section. MRDI is Management and Resources Development Initiative a leading media training organization based in Dhaka, specialized in quality issue-based training and research for news media. MRDI and BHW have now established contacts and will possibly combine their efforts in future journalist workshops. - The audit report found only minor comments where Sida requested an action plan was submitted and found acceptable.
